native Vietnamese term combining 'phòng' (room) and 'vệ sinh' (sanitation), derived from Chinese '卫 生' (wèi shēng)

transcriptions.simplified_pronunciation: phong ve sinh (falling, rising, rising tones)

etymology.notes: borrowed from Chinese 喜欢 (xǐ huan), meaning 'to like' or 'to be fond of'

meanings: to like; to be fond of

etymology.notes: native Vietnamese word for 'West'; used as abbreviation for Spain in historical contexts

meanings: historical abbreviation for Spain (Tây Ban Nha)

etymology.notes: sino-vietnamese term derived from Chinese 西 (xī), meaning 'west'

meanings: western part (of a place or object)

etymology.notes: sino-vietnamese loanword from Chinese 下, meaning 'down' or 'lower'

meanings: to go down; to decline; to fall

etymology.notes: derived from Chinese 下班 (xià bān) with sino-vietnamese adaptation

transcriptions.simplified_pronunciation: tan ca (low-rising tone on tan, high level tone on ca)

meanings: to finish work; to get off work

etymology.notes: Sino-Vietnamese term derived from Chinese 下边, meaning 'under' or 'below'
composed of 'xuống' (down, off) and 'xe' (vehicle), reflecting Chinese '下车' (xià chē) with Sino-Vietnamese adaptation

meanings: to get off (a bus, train, car, etc.)

etymology.notes: direct translation of Chinese 下次 (xià cì), combining native Vietnamese 'lần' (time/occasion) with Sino-Vietnamese 'sau' (after/next)
sino-vietnamese term derived from Chinese 下课 (xià kè), literally 'to finish class'

meanings: to finish class; to get out of class
(fig.) to be dismissed (esp. of a sports coach)

etymology.notes: Sino-Vietnamese term derived from Chinese 下午 (xià wǔ), combining 'xià' (below) and 'wǔ' (noon) to denote the afternoon period
Sino-Vietnamese word from Chinese 雨 (rain), used as a verb meaning 'to rain'
sino-vietnamese loanword from Chinese 先 (xiān), meaning 'before' or 'first'
sino-vietnamese term derived from Chinese 先生, originally meaning 'teacher' or 'gentleman'

meanings: gentleman; respectful term for a man

etymology.notes: sino-vietnamese loanword from Chinese 现在 (xiàn zài), meaning 'present time'

transcriptions.simplified_pronunciation: bây giờ (low-rising then high level tone)

meanings: now; at present; at the moment

etymology.notes: Sino-Vietnamese loanword from Chinese 想, meaning to think or imagine

meanings: to think (about); to think of; to imagine

etymology.notes: sino-Vietnamese loanword from Chinese 小, meaning 'small' or 'few'
native Vietnamese term for 'child' derived from Chinese '小孩儿' (xiǎo hái r), with erhua influence
native Vietnamese term of address for young women, not directly derived from Chinese characters
composed of 'trẻ' (Sino-Vietnamese for 'small' from Chinese 小) and native Vietnamese 'con' (child). Commonly used for children in general.
Sino-Vietnamese loanword from Chinese 小時 (xiǎoshí), meaning 'hour' or 'time'

meanings: hour; time unit (1/24 of a day)

etymology.notes: derived from Chinese 小学 (xiǎo xué), meaning 'primary education', adopted into Vietnamese as a Sino-Vietnamese term

meanings: the education level for children aged 6-12

etymology.notes: sino-vietnamese term derived from Chinese 小学生 (xiǎo xué shēng), combining 小 (tiểu, small) and 学生 (học sinh, student)

transcriptions.simplified_pronunciation: học sinh (low-rising tone on học, mid-rising on sinh)

meanings: figurative: beginner (e.g., in a skill or field)

etymology.notes: sino-vietnamese loanword from Chinese 笑 (xiào), meaning 'to laugh' or 'to smile'
sino-Vietnamese loanword from Chinese 写 (xiě), meaning 'to write' or 'to compose'

meanings: to write; to compose (text, letters, etc.)
to write (a letter) in a formal context

etymology.notes: Vietnamese phrase derived from Chinese meaning, combining native words 'cảm' (to feel) and 'ơn' (grace/merit) to express gratitude
sino-vietnamese loanword from Chinese xīn, meaning 'new' or 'newly'
Sino-Vietnamese term derived from Chinese 新年 (xīn nián), combining 新 (new) and 年 (year). Chữ Nôm form 新春 represents the concept.
derived from French 'dimanche' (Sunday), adopted in Vietnamese for Sunday, reflecting Chinese 星期's association with the seventh day

meanings: Sunday; the seventh day of the week

etymology.notes: direct translation from Chinese 星期日 (xīng qī rì), combining 'chủ' (master) and 'nhật' (sun) to denote 'Sunday'
French loanword for Sunday, adapted from the French term 'samedi' but used in Vietnamese as 'chủ nhật' (literally 'master day')
native Vietnamese verb for 'to go' or 'to walk'
Sino-Vietnamese loanword from Chinese 休息 (xiū xi), meaning 'to rest' or 'to take a break'

meanings: to rest; to take a break

etymology.notes: Sino-Vietnamese loanword from Chinese 學 (xué), representing the concept of learning and study
derived from Chinese 學生 (xué sheng), combining 學 (xué, 'study') and 生 (sheng, 'person')
sino-vietnamese term derived from Chinese 学 (xué) meaning 'to learn' and 翻译 (xí) meaning 'to practice'
sino-vietnamese term combining 'trường' (school) and 'học' (study), derived from Chinese '学校' (xuéxiào)
Sino-Vietnamese loanword from Chinese 学院 (xuéyuàn), meaning 'college' or 'university'
Sino-Vietnamese loanword from Chinese 要, originally meaning 'to demand' or 'important' in classical contexts, adapted in Vietnamese to express 'to want' or 'need'
sino-vietnamese loanword from Chinese 也, used as an adverb meaning 'also' or 'too'
sino-Vietnamese loanword from Chinese yè, originally meaning 'leaf' or 'page' in classical contexts

meanings: page (of a book, document, or website)
leaf (as in a leaf of a plant, though less common in modern usage)

etymology.notes: native Vietnamese term for paternal grandfather, derived from indigenous linguistic roots rather than Chinese loanwords
native Vietnamese numeral for 'one' and article, not directly borrowed from Chinese
sino-vietnamese term derived from Chinese 一半 (yī bàn), meaning 'half' or 'one-half'

meanings: part of something divided into two equal parts

etymology.notes: Sino-Vietnamese term derived from Chinese 一邊 (yī biān), combining 数词 '一' (one) with 方位词 '边' (side)

meanings: on the one hand; on the other hand

etymology.notes: derived from Chinese 一點 (diǎn) with erhua variation, adopted as a measure word for small quantities

meanings: a little bit; a bit (of something)

etymology.notes: native Vietnamese phrase corresponding to Chinese 一会儿, expressing a brief period of time
Vietnamese phrase corresponding to Chinese erhua variant of 一块, conveying collective action or simultaneous occurrence
Sino-Vietnamese term derived from Chinese 一起 (yī qǐ), meaning 'together' or 'with'

meanings: together; with; in the same place

etymology.notes: sino-vietnamese loanword from Chinese 下 (xia), meaning 'down' or 'below'
sino-vietnamese loanword from Chinese yī xiē, meaning 'some' or 'a few'
Sino-Vietnamese loanword from Chinese 'tóng' (同), meaning 'same' or 'equal'

meanings: same; equal to; the same as

etymology.notes: derived from Chinese 衣服 (yīfú), combining 衣 (yī, clothing) and 服 (fú, attire), adapted into Vietnamese as a compound noun
sino-Vietnamese loanword from Chinese 医生 (yī shēng), combining 医 (yī, medicine) and 生 (shēng, person)

transcriptions.simplified_pronunciation: bác sĩ (high tone on first syllable, falling-rising on second)

etymology.notes: sino-vietnamese term derived from Chinese yīyuàn (医院), combining 医 (medical) and 院 (institution)
sino-vietnamese loanword from Chinese 用 (yòng), meaning 'to use' or 'to employ'

meanings: to eat or drink (e.g., 'dùng cơm' = eat rice)

etymology.notes: Sino-Vietnamese loanword from Chinese 有 (yǒu), meaning 'to have' or 'there is'
native Vietnamese verb expressing existence or possession, not derived from Chinese characters

meanings: to have; to exist (in the sense of 'there is/are')

etymology.notes: Sino-Vietnamese term derived from Chinese 有名 (yǒu míng), meaning 'famous' or 'well-known'
derived from Chinese 有時 (yǒu shí) through Sino-Vietnamese loanword adaptation
native Vietnamese adverbial phrase corresponding to Chinese 有时候, used to express temporal frequency
native Vietnamese phrase combining 'một' (one) and 'chút' (a little) to express 'some' or 'somewhat'
native Vietnamese word for 'somewhat' and 'a bit'
native Vietnamese phrase used to express a moderate degree, corresponding to the Chinese measure word phrase 有一些
sino-vietnamese term derived from Chinese 有用 (yǒngyòng), combining 有 (có) 'have' and 用 (ích) 'use'
sino-vietnamese loanword from Chinese 右 (yòu), meaning 'right' and 'right-hand side'

meanings: the right side as the side of precedence

etymology.notes: Sino-Vietnamese term derived from Chinese 右边, meaning 'right side'
Sino-Vietnamese loanword from Chinese 雨 (yǔ), meaning 'rain'; adapted into Chữ Nôm as 雨 (mưa) with native Vietnamese pronunciation
native Vietnamese numeral corresponding to the first position in a sequence
Sino-Vietnamese loanword from Chinese 'yuàn', meaning 'far' or 'distant'. Used as an adjective and noun in Vietnamese.
Sino-Vietnamese loanword from Chinese 月 (yuè), meaning 'moon' or 'month'
Sino-Vietnamese loanword from Chinese 再 (zài), meaning 'again' or 're-' as a prefix
derived from Chinese 再见 (zài jiàn), combining 暂 (tạm, temporarily) and 别 (biệt, to part ways)
Sino-Vietnamese loanword from Chinese 'zài', used to indicate location or ongoing action

meanings: to be located at; to be in a place
used before verbs to indicate an action in progress (e.g., đang ở)

etymology.notes: Vietnamese phrase combining native words 'ở' (to be) and 'nhà' (home) to convey the Chinese meaning of being at home or remaining a layman

meanings: to be at home; (at a workplace) to be in (as opposed to being away on official business)
(Buddhism etc) to remain a layman (as opposed to becoming a monk or a nun)

etymology.notes: sino-vietnamese loanword from Chinese 早 (zǎo), meaning 'early' or 'morning'

meanings: prematurely (in the sense of happening too soon)

etymology.notes: composed of 'bữa' (meal) and 'sáng' (morning), derived from Chinese '早饭' (zǎo fàn) via Sino-Vietnamese

meanings: the first meal of the day

etymology.notes: composed of Sino-Vietnamese words 'sáng' (from Chinese 'cháo' meaning dawn) and 'sớm' (from Chinese 'zǎo' meaning early)

transcriptions.simplified_pronunciation: sáng sớm (high level tone for both syllables)

meanings: the time of day when the sun rises

etymology.notes: Sino-Vietnamese term derived from Chinese 怎么, used as a question particle for 'how?', 'what?', or 'why?'

meanings: variant of 怎么 in Vietnamese context

etymology.notes: sino-vietnamese loanword from Chinese 站, meaning station
sino-vietnamese loanword from Chinese 找 (zhǎo), meaning 'to seek' or 'to find'
Sino-Vietnamese loanword from Chinese 'zhǎo dào' (找到), combining 'zhǎo' (找, to search) and 'dào' (到, to reach)
Sino-Vietnamese pronoun derived from Chinese '这', used to indicate 'this' or 'these' in context

meanings: this; these (followed by classifier, e.g., 'này cuốn sách' = 'this book')

etymology.notes: Vietnamese native term for 'this side' corresponding to Chinese 这边, used in directional contexts
native Vietnamese pronoun for 'here' corresponding to Chinese 这儿
native Vietnamese phrase combining 'ở' (to be) and 'đây' (here) to express location
native Vietnamese demonstrative pronoun corresponding to Chinese 这些
sino-Vietnamese loanword from Chinese 着 (zhuó), originally meaning 'to move' in chess contexts
sino-vietnamese loanword from Chinese 真, meaning 'true' or 'real'
native Vietnamese adjective expressing truth or reality, not directly borrowed from Chinese
Sino-Vietnamese loanword from Chinese 正 (zhèng), meaning 'straight' or 'upright'
native Vietnamese particle indicating an ongoing action or state, corresponding to Chinese 正在's meaning of 'right in the middle of doing something'

meanings: right in the middle of (doing something)

etymology.notes: native Vietnamese verb for 'to know' or 'to become aware of', distinct from sino-vietnamese loanwords

meanings: to know; to become aware of

etymology.notes: Sino-Vietnamese loanword from Chinese 知識 (zhī shi), combining 知 (knowledge) and 识 (understanding)

transcriptions.simplified_pronunciation: kiến thức (low tone on 第一音节, rising tone on 第二音节)

etymology.notes: Sino-Vietnamese term for 'middle' or 'center', derived from Chinese 中. Also used as a prefix in compound words.
sino-Vietnamese term derived from Chinese 中国 (Zhōngguó), combining 中 (zhōng, 'middle') and 国 (guó, 'country')

transcriptions.simplified_pronunciation: Trung Quoc (low-rising tone on 第二音节)

etymology.notes: native Vietnamese preposition expressing spatial/temporal middle, between, or among; not directly borrowed from Chinese
derived from the Chinese character 中 (zhōng, 'middle') via Sino-Vietnamese, with 'Trung' representing the Chinese character in Chữ Nôm
native Vietnamese term for midday, corresponding to Chinese 中午 (zhōng wǔ) in contexts of daily meal times

meanings: the time of day when people take a lunch break

etymology.notes: sino-vietnamese term directly borrowed from Chinese, combining 中 (middle) and 學 (study), referring to secondary education

transcriptions.simplified_pronunciation: trung hoc (low tone on trung, rising tone on hoc)

etymology.notes: loanword from Chinese, combining 'trung học' (middle school) and 'sinh' (student)
sino-vietnamese loanword from Chinese 'zhòng', reflecting the meaning of 'heavy' and 'serious'
sino-vietnamese term derived from Chinese '重要' (zhòng yào), combining 'quan' (related to official matters) and 'trọng' (valuable)

transcriptions.simplified_pronunciation: quan tronh (low tone on 'quan', falling tone on 'trọng')

etymology.notes: sino-Vietnamese loanword from Chinese 'zhù' (住), meaning 'to dwell' or 'to stay'; retained in Vietnamese with semantic shift to include 'reside' and 'stay'

meanings: to live; to dwell; to stay; to reside

etymology.notes: sino-vietnamese loanword from Chinese 准备, meaning 'to prepare' or 'preparation'

transcriptions.simplified_pronunciation: chuẩn bị (low-rising tone on first syllable)

meanings: to intend; to be about to

etymology.notes: native Vietnamese noun for furniture surface, not derived from Chinese characters
derived from Chinese 桌子 (zhuō zi) via Sino-Vietnamese loanword
Sino-Vietnamese loanword from Chinese "zì", originally referring to a single character in writing
native Vietnamese term for 'child' and 'seed'; also used for 'egg' and 'small thing' in specific contexts
native Vietnamese word for child, also used for small things or subordinate entities
sino-vietnamese loanword from Chinese 走, meaning 'to go'
Sino-Vietnamese term combining 'đi' (to go) and 'bộ' (step, walk), reflecting the Chinese character 走路 (zǒu lù)

meanings: to walk; to go on foot

etymology.notes: sino-Vietnamese loanword from Chinese 最 (zuì), used as a superlative suffix in Vietnamese
composed of 'tốt' (Sino-Vietnamese for 'good') and 'nhất' (native Vietnamese for 'first'), used for 'best' and imperative 'had better'
native Vietnamese term for 'final' and 'finally' derived from native vocabulary, not directly from Chinese
Sino-Vietnamese loanword from Chinese 昨天 (zuó tiān), meaning 'the day before yesterday'
Sino-Vietnamese word corresponding to Chinese 左, meaning left and east
native Vietnamese noun/adjective for 'left' and 'left side', distinct from Chinese-derived terms
sino-vietnamese loanword from Chinese, used for 'to sit', 'to take a seat', 'to take (transport)', and 'to bear fruit'

meanings: to sit; to take a seat

etymology.notes: adaptation of Chinese verb phrase 坐下, literally 'sit down' translated as 'ngồi xuống' in Vietnamese

meanings: to sit down; to lower oneself
to descend into a seated position

etymology.notes: Sino-Vietnamese loanword from Chinese 做 (zuò), meaning 'to make' or 'to do'

meanings: to do, to make, to produce
to engage in (an activity), to hold (a party, event)
